title: The Art of War
description: A timeless classic on military strategy and tactics, written by Sun Tzu around 5th century BC. It offers insights into warfare and leadership applicable in various fields beyond the battlefield.

title: To Kill a Mockingbird
description: Harper Lee's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel explores themes of racial injustice and moral growth through the eyes of a young girl in the American South during the 1930s.

title: The Great Gatsby
description: F. Scott Fitzgerald's masterpiece delves into the Jazz Age of the 1920s, depicting the opulence, excess, and disillusionment of the American Dream.
George Orwell's dystopian novel depicts a totalitarian society ruled by omnipresent government surveillance, thought control, and manipulation.

title: Pride and Prejudice
description: Jane Austen's romantic novel explores themes of love, marriage, and social class in early 19th-century England, focusing on the spirited Elizabeth Bennet and the enigmatic Mr. Darcy.

title: The Catcher in the Rye
description: J.D. Salinger's coming-of-age novel follows the disillusioned teenager Holden Caulfield as he navigates the complexities of adolescence, alienation, and identity.

title: The Lord of the Rings
description: J.R.R. Tolkien's epic fantasy trilogy follows the quest to destroy the One Ring, exploring themes of heroism, friendship, and the struggle between good and evil in the fictional world of Middle-earth.

title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone
description: J.K. Rowling's enchanting tale introduces readers to the young wizard Harry Potter as he discovers his magical heritage and embarks on adventures at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.

title: The Hobbit
description: J.R.R. Tolkien's beloved fantasy novel follows the journey of Bilbo Baggins, a hobbit who sets out on an unexpected adventure to reclaim treasure guarded by the dragon Smaug.

title: Moby-Dick
description: Herman Melville's epic novel tells the story of Captain Ahab's obsessive quest for revenge against the white whale Moby Dick, exploring themes of obsession, fate, and the human condition.

title: Brave New World
description: Aldous Huxley's dystopian novel presents a futuristic society where citizens are engineered and conditioned for conformity and stability, exploring themes of freedom, individuality, and technology.

title: The Odyssey
description: Homer's ancient Greek epic poem follows the hero Odysseus on his journey home from the Trojan War, encountering mythical creatures, gods, and challenges along the way.

title: The Grapes of Wrath
description: John Steinbeck's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel portrays the struggles of the Joad family during the Great Depression, highlighting themes of poverty, injustice, and the resilience of the human spirit.

title: One Hundred Years of Solitude
description: Gabriel García Márquez's magical realism masterpiece chronicles the Buendía family over seven generations in the fictional town of Macondo, blending history, myth, and imagination.

title: Crime and Punishment
description: Fyodor Dostoevsky's psychological novel explores the moral dilemmas of the impoverished ex-student Raskolnikov, who commits a murder and grapples with guilt, redemption, and the nature of evil.

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
description: Oscar Wilde's philosophical novel tells the story of Dorian Gray, a young man who remains eternally youthful while his portrait ages, exploring themes of vanity, hedonism, and the pursuit of beauty.
